title: Understanding SQL JOINs
text: In SQL, a JOIN clause is used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them. This is essential for retrieving data that is spread across multiple tables.

hintAnswer: To retrieve data from multiple tables based on a related column.
title: Identifying the Purpose of JOINs
text: Why would you use a JOIN operation in SQL?
choices: To retrieve data from multiple tables based on a related column.
To create a new table with unrelated data.
To delete rows from multiple tables simultaneously.
To update data in a single table.

title: Types of JOINs
text: There are several types of JOINs in SQL, including INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN. Each type serves a different purpose in how it combines data from tables.

title: Choosing the Correct JOIN Type
text: Which type of JOIN would you use to include all records from the left table and the matched records from the right table?

title: JOIN Syntax
text: The basic syntax for a JOIN operation in SQL is: SELECT columns FROM table1 JOIN table2 ON table1.column $$=$$ table2.column;

hintAnswer: SELECT * FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department_id $$=$$ departments.department_id;
